wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Performs morphological operations on an input image channel
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application performs binary morphological operations on a mono band image

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Apply a smoothing filter to an image
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application applies smoothing filter to an image. Either gaussian, mean, or anisotropic diffusion are available.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Generates a subsampled version of an image extract
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Generates a subsampled version of an extract of an image defined by ROIStart and ROISize. This extract is subsampled using the ratio OR the output image Size.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Apply a transform to each vertex of the input VectorData
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application performs a transformation of an input vector data transforming each vertex in the vector data. The applied transformation manages translation, rotation and scale, and can be centered or not.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Extract a ROI defined by the user.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application extracts a Region Of Interest with user defined size, or reference image.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Computes global mean and standard deviation for each band from a set of images and optionally saves the results in an XML file.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application computes a global mean and standard deviation for each band of a set of images and optionally saves the results in an XML file. The output XML is intended to be used an input for the TrainImagesClassifier application to normalize samples before learning.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Filters the input labeled image using Majority Voting in a ball shaped neighbordhood.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application filters the input labeled image (with a maximal class label = 65535) using Majority Voting in a ball shaped neighbordhood. Majority Voting takes the more representative value of all the pixels identified by the ball shaped structuring element and then sets the center pixel to this majority label value. -NoData is the label of the NOT classified pixels in the input image. These input pixels keep their NoData label in the output image. -Pixels with more than 1 majority class are marked as Undecided if the parameter 'ip.suvbool == true', or keep their Original labels otherwise.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Export the input image in a KMZ product.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application exports the input image in a kmz product that can be display in the Google Earth software. The user can set the size of the product size, a logo and a legend to the product. Furthemore, to obtain a product that fits the relief, a DEM can be used.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Perform mean shift filtering
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application performs mean shift fitlering (multi-threaded).

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert an image to a different format, eventually rescaling the data and/or changing the pixel type.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application performs an image pixel type conversion (short, ushort, uchar, int, uint, float and double types are handled). The output image is written in the specified format (ie. that corresponds to the given extension). The convertion can include a rescale using the image 2 percent minimum and maximum values. The rescale can be linear or log2.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Projects a disparity map into a regular elevation map
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application uses a disparity map computed from a stereo image pair to produce an elevation map on the ground area covered by the stereo pair. The needed inputs are : the disparity map, the stereo pair (in original geometry) and the epipolar deformation grids. These grids have to link the original geometry (stereo pair) and the epipolar geometry (disparity map).

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Generates two deformation fields to stereo-rectify (i.e. resample in epipolar geometry) a pair of stereo images up to the sensor model precision
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application generates a pair of deformation grid to stereo-rectify a pair of stereo images according to sensor modelling and a mean elevation hypothesis. The deformation grids can be passed to the StereoRectificationGridGenerator application for actual resampling in epipolar geometry.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Estimator between 2 images.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application computes MSE (Mean Squared Error), MAE (Mean Absolute Error) and PSNR (Peak Signal to Noise Ratio) between the channel of two images (reference and measurement). The user has to set the used channel and can specify a ROI.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Resample an image with a rigid transform
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application performs a parametric transform on the input image. Scaling, translation and rotation with scaling factor are handled. Parameters of the transform is expressed in physical units, thus particular attention must be paid on pixel size (value, and sign). Moreover transform is expressed from input space to output space (on the contrary ITK Transforms are expressed form output space to input space).

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Concatenate VectorDatas
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application concatenates a list of VectorData to produce a unique VectorData as output.Note that the VectorDatas must be of the same type (Storing polygons only, lines only, or points only)

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Set a field in vector data.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Set a specified field to a specified value on all features of a vector data.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Get information about the image
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Display information about the input image like: image size, origin, spacing, metadata, projections...

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Compare two segmentations with Hoover metrics
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application compares a machine segmentation (MS) with a partial ground truth segmentation (GT). The Hoover metrics are used to estimate scores for correct detection, over-segmentation, under-segmentation and missed detection. The application can output the overall Hoover scores along with coloredimages of the MS and GT segmentation showing the state of each region (correct detection, over-segmentation, under-segmentation, missed) The Hoover metrics are described in : Hoover et al., "An experimental comparison of range image segmentation algorithms", IEEE PAMI vol. 18, no. 7, July 1996.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Estimate disparity map between two images.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Estimate disparity map between two images. Output image contain x offset, y offset and metric value.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Get the value of a pixel.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Get the value of a pixel.Pay attention, index starts at 0.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Computes textures on every pixel of the input image selected channel
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application computes Haralick, advanced and higher order textures on a mono band image

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Fusion of an image made of several tile files.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Concatenate several tile files into a single image file.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Detect line segments in raster
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application detects locally straight contours in a image. It is based on Burns, Hanson, and Riseman method and use an a contrario validation approach (Desolneux, Moisan, and Morel). The algorithm was published by Rafael Gromponevon Gioi, JÃ©rÃ©mie Jakubowicz, Jean-Michel Morel and Gregory Randall. The given approach computes gradient and level lines of the image and detects aligned points in line support region. The application allows to export the detected lines in a vector data.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Performs block-matching to estimate pixel-wise disparities between two images
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application allows to performs block-matching to estimate pixel-wise disparities between two images. The application allows to choose the block-matching method to use. It also allows to input masks (related to the left and right input image) of pixels for which the disparity should be investigated. Additionally, two criteria can be optionally used to disable disparity investigation for some pixel: a no-data value, and a threshold on the local variance. This allows to speed-up computation by avoiding to investigate disparities that will not be reliable anyway. For efficiency reasons, if the optimal metric values image is desired, it will be concatenated to the output image (which will then have three bands : horizontal disparity, vertical disparity and metric value). One can split these images afterward.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Multivariate Alteration Detector
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application detects change between two given images.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Rescale the image between two given values.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application scales the given image pixel intensity between two given values. By default min (resp. max) value is set to 0 (resp. 255).

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Computes the confusion matrix of a classification
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application computes the confusion matrix of a classification map relatively to a ground truth. This ground truth can be given as a raster or a vector data. Only reference and produced pixels with values different from NoData are handled in the calculation of the confusion matrix. The confusion matrix is organized the following way: rows = reference labels, columns = produced labels. In the header of the output file, the reference and produced class labels are ordered according to the rows/columns of the confusion matrix.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Find endmembers in hyperspectral images with Vertex Component Analysis
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Applies the Vertex Component Analysis to an hyperspectral image to extract endmembers

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Perform speckle noise reduction on SAR image.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application reduce speckle noise. Two methods are available: Lee and Frost.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Generate a vector data from OSM on the input image extend
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Generate a vector data from Open Street Map data. A DEM could be use. By default, the entire layer is downloaded, an image can be use as support for the OSM data. The application can provide also available classes in layers . This application required an Internet access. Informations about the OSM project : http://www.openstreetmap.fr/

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: This application helps developers to test parameters types
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The purpose of this application is to test parameters types.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Split a N multiband image into N images
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application splits a N-bands image into N mono-band images. The output images filename will be generated from the output parameter. Thus if the input image has 2 channels, and the user has set an output outimage.tif, the generated images will be outimage_0.tif and outimage_1.tif

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Compute the ground elevation based on one or multiple stereo pair(s)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Compute the ground elevation with a stereo block matching algorithm between one or mulitple stereo pair in sensor geometry. The output is projected in desired geographic or cartographic map projection (UTM by default). The pipeline is made of the following steps:for each sensor pair :- compute the epipolar displacement grids from the stereo pair (direct and inverse)- resample the stereo pair into epipolar geometry using BCO interpolation- create masks for each epipolar image : remove black borders and resample input masks- compute horizontal disparities with a block matching algorithm- refine disparities to sub-pixel precision with a dichotomy algorithm- apply an optional median filter- filter disparities based on the correlation score and exploration bounds- translate disparities in sensor geometry convert disparity to 3D Map.Then fuse all 3D maps to produce DSM.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Generate a 3D Ply file from a DEM and a color image.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Generate a 3D Ply file from a DEM and a color image.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Perform a mathematical operation on monoband images
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application performs a mathematical operation on monoband images. Mathematical formula interpretation is done via MuParser libraries http://muparser.sourceforge.net/

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Perform an extract ROI on the input vector data according to the input image extent
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application extracts the vector data features belonging to a region specified by the support image envelope. Any features intersecting the support region is copied to output. The output geometries are NOT cropped.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Resamples an image according to a resampling grid
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application allows to perform image resampling from an input resampling grid.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Estimate abundance maps from an hyperspectral image and a set of endmembers.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The application applies a linear unmixing algorithm to an hyperspectral data cube. This method supposes that the mixture between materials in the scene is macroscopic and simulates a linear mixing model of spectra.The Linear Mixing Model (LMM) acknowledges that reflectance spectrum associated with each pixel is a linear combination of pure materials in the recovery area, commonly known as endmembers. Endmembers can be estimated using the VertexComponentAnalysis application.The application allows to estimate the abundance maps with several algorithms : Unconstrained Least Square (ucls), Fully Constrained Least Square (fcls), Image Space Reconstruction Algorithm (isra) and Non-negative constrained Least Square (ncls) and Minimum Dispertion Constrained Non Negative Matrix Factorization (MDMDNMF).

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Perform Dimension reduction of the input image.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Performs dimensionality reduction on input image. PCA,NA-PCA,MAF,ICA methods are available. It is also possible to compute the inverse transform to reconstruct the image. It is also possible to optionnaly export the transformation matrix to a text file.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Rasterize a vector dataset.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application allows to reproject and rasterize a vector dataset. The grid of the rasterized output can be set by using a reference image, or by setting all parmeters (origin, size, spacing) by hand. In the latter case, at least the spacing (ground sampling distance) is needed (other parameters are computed automatically). The rasterized output can also be in a different projection reference system than the input dataset. There are two rasterize mode available in the application. The first is the binary mode: it allows to render all pixels belonging to a geometry of the input dataset in the foreground color, while rendering the other in background color. The second one allows to render pixels belonging to a geometry woth respect to an attribute of this geometry. The field of the attribute to render can be set by the user. In the second mode, the background value is still used for unassociated pixels.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Build a multi-resolution pyramid of the image.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application builds a multi-resolution pyramid of the input image. User can specified the number of levels of the pyramid and the subsampling factor. To speed up the process, you can use the fast scheme option

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Connected component segmentation and object based image filtering of the input image according to user-defined criterions.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application allows to perform a masking, connected components segmentation and object based image filtering. First and optionally, a mask can be built based on user-defined criterions to select pixels of the image which will be segmented. Then a connected component segmentation is performed with a user defined criterion to decide whether two neighbouring pixels belong to the same segment or not. After this segmentation step, an object based image filtering is applied using another user-defined criterion reasoning on segment properties, like shape or radiometric attributes. Criterions are mathematical expressions analysed by the MuParser library (http://muparser.sourceforge.net/). For instance, expression "((b1>80) and intensity>95)" will merge two neighbouring pixel in a single segment if their intensity is more than 95 and their value in the first image band is more than 80. See parameters documentation for a list of available attributes. The output of the object based image filtering is vectorized and can be written in shapefile or KML format. If the input image is in raw geometry, resulting polygons will be transformed to WGS84 using sensor modelling before writing, to ensure consistency with GIS softwares. For this purpose, a Digital Elevation Model can be provided to the application. The whole processing is done on a per-tile basis for large images, so this application can handle images of arbitrary size.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Performs morphological operations on a grayscale input image
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application performs grayscale morphological operations on a mono band image

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Computes Structural Feature Set textures on every pixel of the input image selected channel
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application computes SFS textures on a mono band image

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Concatenate a list of images of the same size into a single multi-channel one.
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This application performs images channels concatenation. It will walk the input image list (single or multi-channel) and generates a single multi-channel image. The channel order is the one of the list.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: MMF-SAGA Soil Erosion Model
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Soil erosion modelling with a modified MMF (Morgan-Morgan-Finney) model (Morgan & Duzant 2008).<br/>This module is called MMF-SAGA because some things have been implemented differently compared to the original publication. The most important are:<br/><br/><ul><li>the extension of the model to support spatially distributed modelling</li><li>the introduction of a "Channel Network" layer</li><li>the introduction of a "rainfall duration" (time span) parameter</li><li>the exposure of the flow depth parameter</li></ul><br/><br/>A more detailed description of the model, its modifications, and model application is provided by Setiawan (2012), chapter 6.<br/>Currently, a number of additional grid datasets are outputted to facilitate model evaluation. This can be easily changed within the source code.<br/><br/><br/>References:<br/><b>Morgan, R.P.C. (2001)</b>: A simple approach to soil loss prediction: a revised Morgan-Morgan-Finney model. Catena 44: 305-322.<br/><br/><b>Morgan, R.P.C., Duzant, J.H. (2008)</b>: Modified MMF (Morgan-Morgan-Finney) model for evaluating effects of crops and vegetation cover on soil erosion. Earth Surf. Process. Landforms 32: 90-106.<br/><br/><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/saga-gis/files/SAGA%20-%20Documentation/Modules/MMF-SAGA_Setiawan.pdf"><b>Setiawan, M. A. (2012)</b>: Integrated Soil Erosion Management in the upper Serayu Watershed, Wonosobo District, Central Java Province, Indonesia. Dissertation at the Faculty of Geo- and Atmospheric Sciences of the University of Innsbruck, Austria.</a><br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Channel Network and Drainage Basins
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Deterministic 8 based flow network analysis<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Watershed Basins
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Watershed Basins

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Valley Depth
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Valley depth is calculated here vertical distance to a channel network base level. The algorithm consists of two major steps:<br/> 1. Interpolation of a channel network base level elevation<br/> 2. Subtraction of this base level from the original elevations<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Channel Network
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module derives a channel network based on gridded digital elevation data.<br/>Use the initiation options to determine under which conditions channels shall start.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Strahler Order
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: (c) 2004 by Victor Olaya. Strahler Order Calculation

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Overland Flow Distance to Channel Network
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module calculates overland flow distances to a channel network based on gridded digital elevation data and channel network information. The flow algorithm may be either Deterministic 8 (O'Callaghan & Mark 1984) or Multiple Flow Direction (Freeman 1991). Sediment Delivery Rates (SDR) according to Ali & De Boer (2010) can be computed optionally. <br/><br/>References:<br/>- Ali, K. F., De Boer, D. H. (2010): Spatially distributed erosion and sediment yield modeling in the upper Indus River basin. Water Resources Research, 46(8), W08504. doi:10.1029/2009WR008762<br/>- Freeman, G.T., 1991: Calculating catchment area with divergent flow based on a regular grid. Computers and Geosciences, 17:413-22.<br/>- O'Callaghan, J.F., Mark, D.M., 1984: The extraction of drainage networks from digital elevation data. Computer Vision, Graphics and Image Processing, 28:323-344.<br/>- Nobre, A.D., Cuartas, L.A., Hodnett, M., Renno, C.D., Rodrigues, G., Silveira, A., Waterloo, M., Saleska S. (2011): Height Above the Nearest Drainage - a hydrologically relevant new terrain model. Journal of Hydrology, Vol. 404, Issues 1-2, pp. 13-29, ISSN 0022-1694, 10.1016/j.jhydrol.2011.03.051. <a target="_blank" href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022169411002599">online</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Vertical Distance to Channel Network
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module calculates the vertical distance to a channel network base level. The algorithm consists of two major steps:<br/> 1. Interpolation of a channel network base level elevation<br/> 2. Subtraction of this base level from the original elevations<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Watershed Basins (Extended)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Extended watershed basin analysis.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Line Dissolve
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Dissolves line shapes, which share the same attribute value(s).

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert Points to Line(s)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Converts points to line(s).

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert Polygons to Lines
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Convert polygons to lines.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Split Lines with Lines
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Split Lines with Lines.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Line Simplification
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Line simplification implementing the Ramer-Douglas-Peucker algorithm.<br/><br/>Refererences:<br/>- Ramer, U. (1972): An iterative procedure for the polygonal approximation of plane curves. Computer Graphics and Image Processing, 1(3), 244-256<br/>- Douglas, D., Peucker, T. (1973): Algorithms for the reduction of the number of points required to represent a digitized line or its caricature. The Canadian Cartographer 10(2), 112-122<br/><br/>- Polyline Reduction source code at <a target="_blank" href="http://mappinghacks.com/code/PolyLineReduction/">mappinghacks.com</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Line-Polygon Intersection
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Line-polygon intersection.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Line Properties
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Line properties: length, number of vertices.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Difference
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the geometric difference of the overlayed polygon layers, i.e. layer A less layer B. Sometimes referred to as 'Erase' command.<br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygon Dissolve
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Merges polygons, which share the same attribute value, and (optionally) dissolves borders between adjacent polygon parts. If no attribute or combination of attributes is chosen, all polygons will be merged. <br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygons to Edges and Nodes
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Polygons to Edges and Nodes

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygon Parts to Separate Polygons
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Splits parts of multipart polygons into separate polygons. This can be done only for islands (outer rings) or for all parts (inner and outer rings) by checking the 'ignore lakes' option.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygon Centroids
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Creates a points layer containing the centroids of the input polygon layer.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygon Shape Indices
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Various indices describing the shape of polygons. Based on area, perimeter, maximum distance between the vertices of a polygon.<br/><br/> - Interior Edge Ratio (Perimeter / Area)<br/> - Shape Index (Perimeter / (2 * SquareRoot(PI * Area))<br/><br/>References:<br/>Lang, S., Blaschke, T. (2007): Landschaftsanalyse mit GIS.<br/><br/>Forman, R.T.T., Godron, M. (1986): Landscape Ecology. Cambridge.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Add Point Attributes to Polygons
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Spatial join for polygons. Retrieves for each polygon the selected attributes from that point, which is contained in the polygon. In case a polygon contains more than one point, the last point wins.<br/>Optionally, the module allows one to attach the geometrical properties (x,y(z,m)) of each point as additional attributes.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygon-Line Intersection
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Polygon-line intersection. Splits polygons with lines.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Shared Polygon Edges
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Shared Polygon Edges

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert Polygon/Line Vertices to Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Convert Polygon/Line Vertices to Points

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Point Statistics for Polygons
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates statistics over all points falling in a polygon.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Symmetrical Difference
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the symmetrical geometric difference of the overlayed polygon layers, i.e. layer A less layer B plus layer B less layer A.<br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Identity
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the geometric intersection between both layers and adds the difference of layer A less layer B.<br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert Lines to Polygons
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Converts lines to polygons. Line arcs are closed to polygons simply by connecting the last point with the first. Optionally parts of polylines can be merged into one polygon optionally.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Intersect
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the geometric intersection of the overlayed polygon layers, i.e. layer A and layer B.<br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygon Properties
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: General and geometric properties of polygons.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Union
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the geometric union of the overlayed polygon layers, i.e. the intersection plus the symmetrical difference of layers A and B.<br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Flatten Polygon Layer
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Removes invalid polygons, i.e. polygons with less than three vertices, and merges polygons belonging spatially together, i.e. forming outer and inner rings. Inner rings are not preserved as separate polygon, but become new part of the polygon forming the outer ring.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygon Clipping
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Clipping of vector layers with a polygon layer.<br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polygon Self-Intersection
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Self-intersection of one layer's polygons.<br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Update
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Updates features of layer A with the features of layer B, i.e. all features of layer B will be supplemented with the difference of layer A less layer B plus. It is assumed, that both input layers share the same attribute structure.<br/>Uses the free and open source software library <b>Clipper</b> created by Angus Johnson.<br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.angusj.com/delphi/clipper.php">Clipper Homepage</a><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/polyclipping/">Clipper at SourceForge</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Split Shapes Layer
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Split Shapes Layer

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Split Shapes Layer Completely
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Copies each shape of given layer to a separate target layer.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Transform Shapes
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: (c) 2004 by Victor Olaya. Use this module to move, rotate and/or scale shapes.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert Vertex Type (2D/3D)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The module allows to convert the vertex type of shapes from 'XY' (2D) to 'XYZ/M' (3D) and vice versa. The conversion from 3D to 2D is not lossless for lines and polygons, as only the Z/M value of one vertex can be retained (currently that of the last vertex).<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Cut Shapes Layer
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Cut Shapes Layer

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: QuadTree Structure to Shapes
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: QuadTree Structure to Shapes

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Create New Shapes Layer
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Creates a new empty shapes layer of given type, which might be either point, multipoint, line or polygon. Possible field types for the attributes table are:<br/> - character string<br/> - 1 byte integer<br/> - 2 byte integer<br/> - 4 byte integer<br/> - 4 byte floating point<br/> - 8 byte floating point<br/> - 32 bit true color (RGB)<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Generate Shapes
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The module allows to generate point, line or polygon shapes from a table with x and y coordinates and an identifier. The table must be sorted in vertex order.<br/><br/>The identifier has different meanings:<br/><br/>* Point Shapes: The identifier is arbitrary<br/><br/>* Line Shapes: The identifier is unique for each line<br/><br/>* Polygon Shapes: The identifier is unique for each polygon; the first polygon vertex may but must not be duplicated in order to close the polygon<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Copy Selection to New Shapes Layer
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Copies selected shapes to a new shapes layer.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Split Shapes Layer Randomly
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Randomly splits one shapes layer into to new shapes layers. Useful to create a control group for model testing.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Get Shapes Extents
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Get Shapes Extents

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Merge Layers
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Merge vector layers.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Split Table/Shapes by Attribute
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Split Table/Shapes by Attribute

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Polar to Cartesian Coordinates
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Polar to Cartesian Coordinates

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Merge Tables
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Merge tables.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Create Graticule
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: (c) 2004 by Victor Olaya.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Shapes Buffer
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: A vector based buffer construction partly based on the method supposed by Dong et al. 2003. <br/><br/>References:<br/>Dong, P, Yang, C., Rui, X., Zhang, L., Cheng, Q. (2003): 'An effective buffer generation method in GIS'. Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium, 2003. IGARSS '03. Proceedings. 2003 IEEE International, Vol.6, p.3706-3708.<br/><a href="http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/iel5/9010/28606/01295244.pdf">online version</a><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Zonal Grid Statistics
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The module calculates zonal statistics and reports these in a table. The module can be used to create a contingency table of unique condition units (UCUs). These units are delineated from a zonal grid (e.g. sub catchments) and optional categorical grids (e.g. landcover, soil, ...). It is possible to calculate descriptive statistics (n, min, max, mean, standard deviation and sum) for each UCU from optional grids with continious data (e.g. slope; aspect must be handled specially, please use the "Aspect" input parameter for such a grid). The number of input grids is only limited by available memory.<br/><br/>The module has four different modes of operation:<br/>(1) only a zonal grid is used as input. This results in a simple contingency table with the number of grid cells in each zone.<br/>(2) a zonal grid and additional categorical grids are used as input. This results in a contingency table with the number of cells in each UCU.<br/>(3) a zonal grid and additional grids with continuous data are used as input. This results in a contingency table with the number of cells in each zone and some simple statistics for each zone. The statistics are calculated for each continuous grid.<br/>(4) a zonal grid, additional categorical grids and additional grids with continuous data are used as input. This results in a contingency table with the number of cells in each UCU and the corresponding statistics for each continuous grid.<br/><br/>Depending on the mode of operation, the output table contains information about the categorical combination of each UCU, the number of cells in each UCU and the statistics for each UCU. A typical output table may look like this:<br/><table border="1"><tr><td>ID Zone</td><td>ID 1stCat</td><td>ID 2ndCat</td><td>Count UCU</td><td>N 1stCont</td><td>MIN 1stCont</td><td>MAX 1stCont</td><td>MEAN 1stCont</td><td>STDDEV 1stCont</td><td>SUM 1stCont</td></tr><tr><td>0 </td><td>2 </td><td>6 </td><td>6 </td><td>6 </td><td>708.5 </td><td>862.0 </td><td>734.5 </td><td>62.5 </td><td>4406.8 </td></tr><tr><td>0 </td><td>3 </td><td>4 </td><td>106 </td><td>106 </td><td>829.1 </td><td>910.1 </td><td>848.8 </td><td>28.5 </td><td>89969.0 </td></tr></table>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Multi-Band Variation
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Multi-Band Variation

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Inverse Principle Components Rotation
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Inverse principle components rotation for grids. <br/>References:<br/>Bahrenberg, G., Giese, E., Nipper, J. (1992): Statistische Methoden in der Geographie 2 - Multivariate Statistik. pp.198-277.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Save Grid Statistics to Table
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates statistical properties (arithmetic mean, minimum, maximum, variance, standard deviation) for each of the given grids and saves it to a table.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Residual Analysis (Grid)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Relations of each grid cell to its neighborhood. Wilson & Gallant (2000) used this type of calculation in terrain analysis.<br/><br/>Reference:<br/>- Wilson, J.P., Gallant, J.C., [Eds.] (2000): 'Terrain analysis - principles and applications', New York, John Wiley & Sons, Inc.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Global Moran's I for Grids
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Global spatial autocorrelation for grids calculated as Moran's I.<br/><br/>References:<br/>- Lloyd, C.D. (2010): Spatial data analysis - An introduction for GIS users. Oxford. 206p.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Fast Representativeness
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Fast Representativeness

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Principle Components Analysis
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Principle Components Analysis (PCA) for grids. Implementation based on F. Murtagh's <a target="_blank" href="http://lib.stat.cmu.edu/multi/pca.c">code</a> as provided by the <a target="_blank" href="http://lib.stat.cmu.edu">StatLib</a> web site.<br/><br/>References:<br/>Bahrenberg, G., Giese, E., Nipper, J. (1992): Statistische Methoden in der Geographie 2 - Multivariate Statistik. pp.198-277.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Directional Statistics for Single Grid
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates for each cell statistical properties (arithmetic mean, minimum, maximum, variance, standard deviation) of all cells lying in given direction based on the input grid.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Statistics for Grids
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates statistical properties (arithmetic mean, minimum, maximum, variance, standard deviation) for each cell position for the values of the selected grids.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Radius of Variance (Grid)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Find the radius within which the cell values exceed the given variance criterium. This module is closely related to the representativeness calculation (variance within given search radius). For easier usage, the variance criterium is entered as standard deviation value.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Representativeness (Grid)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Representativeness - calculation of the variance within a given search radius.<br/><br/>Reference:<br/>- Boehner, J., Koethe, R., Trachinow, C. (1997): 'Weiterentwicklung der automatischen Reliefanalyse auf der Basis von Digitalen Gelaendemodellen', Goettinger Geographische Abhandlungen, Vol.100, p.3-21<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Longitudinal Grid Statistics
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Longitudinal Grid Statistics

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Meridional Grid Statistics
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Meridional Grid Statistics

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Gradient Vectors from Surface
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Create lines indicating the gradient.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Contour Lines from Grid
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Create contour lines (isolines) from grid values.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Local Minima and Maxima
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Extracts local grid value minima and maxima of to vector points.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Grid System Extent
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Creates a polygon (rectangle) from a grid system's extent.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Add Grid Values to Shapes
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Spatial Join: Retrieves information from the selected grids at the positions of the shapes of the selected shapes layer and adds it to the resulting shapes layer. For points this is similar to 'Add Grid Values to Points' module. For lines and polygons average values will be calculated from interfering grid cells. For polygons the 'Grid Statistics for Polygons' module offers more advanced options.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Clip Grid with Polygon
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Clips the input grid with a polygon shapefile. Select polygons from the shapefile prior to module execution in case you like to use only a subset from the shapefile for clipping.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Add Grid Values to Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Spatial Join: Retrieves information from the selected grids at the positions of the points of the selected points layer and adds it to the resulting layer.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Vectorising Grid Classes
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Vectorising grid classes.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Grid Values to Points (randomly)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Extract randomly points from gridded data.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Gradient Vectors from Direction and Length
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Gradient Vectors from Direction and Length

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Grid Values to Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module saves grid values to point (grid nodes) or polygon (grid cells) shapes. Optionally only points can be saved, which are contained by polygons of the specified shapes layer. In addition, it is possible to exclude all cells that are coded NoData in the first grid of the grid list.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Grid Statistics for Polygons
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: For each polygon statistics about the values of all contained grid nodes will be generated.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Gradient Vectors from Directional Components
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Gradient Vectors from Directional Components

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Clip Grid with Rectangle
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Clips the input grid with the (rectangular) extent of a shapefile. The clipped grid will have the extent of the shapefile.<br/>Select shapes from the shapefile prior to module execution in case you like to use only a subset from the shapefile for clipping.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Flow Accumulation (Trace)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the catchment area based on the selected elevation values.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Grid to TIN (Surface Specific Points)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Creates a TIN by identifying (surface) specific points of a grid.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Grid to TIN
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Creates a TIN from grid points. No data values will be ignored.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Flow Accumulation (Parallel)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the catchment area based on the selected elevation values.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Gradient
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the gradient based on the values of each triangle's points.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: TIN to Shapes
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Converts a TIN data set to shapes layers.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Shapes to TIN
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Convert a shapes layer to a TIN<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: 02: Carbon Cycle Simulation for Terrestrial Biomass
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Simulation of the Carbon Cycle in Terrestrial Biomass. <br/>Reference:<br/>Hugget, R.J. (1993): 'Modelling the Human Impact on Nature', Oxford University Press.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: 01: A Simple Litter System
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: A simple litter system model using the euler method. Carbon storage C is calculated in dependency of litter fall rate (Cinput) and rate constant for litter loss (Closs) as:<br/>C(t + 1) = C(t) + (Cinput - Closs * C(t)) * dt<br/><br/>Typical values:<br/><br/>- Tropical Rainforest:<br/>-- Litter fall rate: 500 [g/m<sup>2</sup>/a]<br/>-- Litter loss rate: 2.0 [1/a]<br/><br/>- Temperate forest:<br/>-- Litter fall rate: 240 [g/m<sup>2</sup>/a]<br/>-- Litter loss rate: 0.4 [1/a]<br/><br/>- Boreal forest:<br/>-- Litter fall rate: 50 [g/m<sup>2</sup>/a]<br/>-- Litter loss rate: 0.05 [1/a]<br/><br/>Reference:<br/>Hugget, R.J. (1993): 'Modelling the Human Impact on Nature', Oxford University Press.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: 03: Spatially Distributed Simulation of Soil Nitrogen Dynamics
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Spatially Distributed Simulation of Soil Nitrogen Dynamics. <br/>Reference:<br/>Hugget, R.J. (1993): 'Modelling the Human Impact on Nature', Oxford University Press.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Variogram Cloud
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Variogram Cloud

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Variogram
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Variogram

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Spatial Point Pattern Analysis
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Basic measures for spatial point patterns.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Minimum Distance Analysis
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Minimum Distance Analysis

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Variogram Surface
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Variogram Surface

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert Multipoints to Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Converts multipoints to points.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert Lines to Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Converts lines to points. Optionally inserts additional points in user-defined distances.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Separate points by direction
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Separates points by direction. Direction is determined as average direction of three consecutive points A, B, C. If the angle between the directions of A-B and B-C is higher than given tolerance angle the point is dropped. This module has been designed to separate GPS tracks recorded by tractors while preparing a field.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Add Polygon Attributes to Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Spatial join for points. Retrieves for each point the selected attributes from those polygon, which contain the point.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Remove Duplicate Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Remove Duplicate Points

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Snap Points to Grid
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Moves all points to grid cell positions that have the highest orlowest value respectively within the given search distance around each point.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convert Table to Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Create Point Theme From Table

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Clip Points with Polygons
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Clip Points with Polygons

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Add Coordinates to points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The module attaches the x- and y-coordinates of each point to the attribute table. For 3D shapefiles, also the z/m-coordinates are reported.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Fit N Points to shape
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: (c) 2004 by Victor Olaya. Fit N Points to shape

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Thiessen Polygons
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Creates Thiessen or Voronoi polygons for given point data set.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Snap Points to Lines
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Snap Points to Lines

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Point Distances
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Computes distances between pairs of points.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Points Thinning
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Points Thinning

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Create Point Grid
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: (c) 2004 by Victor Olaya. Creates a regular grid of points.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Aggregate Point Observations
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Aggregate Point Observations

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Points Filter
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Points Filter

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Convex Hull
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Implementation of 'Andrew's Monotone Chain Algorithm' for convex hull construction. <br/>References:<br/>Algorithmist (2011): <a target="_blank" href="http://www.algorithmist.com/index.php/Monotone_Chain_Convex_Hull.cpp">Monotone Chain Convex Hull</a>. algorithmist.com.<br/>Andrew, A.M. (1979): Another Efficient Algorithm for Convex Hulls in Two Dimensions. Info. Proc. Letters 9, pp.216-219.<br/>Sunday, D. (2001-2006): <a target="_blank" href="http://www.softsurfer.com/Archive/algorithm_0109">The Convex Hull of a 2D Point Set or Polygon</a>. Softsurfer.com.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Snap Points to Points
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Snap Points to Points

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: SAGA Wetness Index
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The 'SAGA Wetness Index' is, as the name says, similar to the 'Topographic Wetness Index' (TWI), but it is based on a modified catchment area calculation ('Modified Catchment Area'), which does not think of the flow as very thin film. As result it predicts for cells situated in valley floors with a small vertical distance to a channel a more realistic, higher potential soil moisture compared to the standard TWI calculation.<br/><br/>References<br/>- Boehner, J., Koethe, R. Conrad, O., Gross, J., Ringeler, A., Selige, T. (2002): Soil Regionalisation by Means of Terrain Analysis and Process Parameterisation. In: Micheli, E., Nachtergaele, F., Montanarella, L. [Ed.]: Soil Classification 2001. European Soil Bureau, Research Report No. 7, EUR 20398 EN, Luxembourg. pp.213-222.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: LS-Factor, Field Based
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculation of slope length (LS) factor as used for the Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE), based on slope and (specific) catchment area, latter as substitute for slope length. This tool takes only a Digital Elevation Model (DEM) as input and derives catchment areas according to Freeman (1991). Optionally field polygons can be supplied. Is this the case, calculations will be performed field by field, i.e. catchment area calculation is restricted to each field's area. <br/>References:<br/><br/>Boehner, J., Selige, T. (2006): Spatial Prediction of Soil Attributes Using Terrain Analysis and Climate Regionalisation. In: Boehner, J., McCloy, K.R., Strobl, J.: 'SAGA - Analysis and Modelling Applications', Goettinger Geographische Abhandlungen, 115, 13-27.<br/><br/>Desmet, P.J.J., Govers, G. (1996): A GIS Procedure for Automatically Calculating the USLE LS Factor on Topographically Complex Landscape Units. Journal of Soil and Water Conservation, 51(5), 427-433.<br/><br/>Freeman, G.T. (1991): Calculating catchment area with divergent flow based on a regular grid. Computers and Geosciences, 17:413-22<br/><br/>Kinnell, P.I.A. (2005): Alternative Approaches for Determining the USLE-M Slope Length Factor for Grid Cells. <a href="online">https://www.soils.org/publications/sssaj/abstracts/69/3/0674</a><br/><br/>Moore, I.D., Grayson, R.B., Ladson, A.R. (1991): Digital terrain modelling: a review of hydrogical, geomorphological, and biological applications. Hydrological Processes, 5(1).<br/><br/>Moore, I.D., Nieber, J.L. (1991): Landscape assessment of soil erosion and nonpoint source pollution. J. Minnesota Acad. Sci., 55, 18-25.<br/><br/>Wischmeier, W.H., Smith, D.D. (1978): Predicting rainfall erosion losses - A guide to conservation planning. Agriculture Handbook No. 537: US Department of Agriculture, Washington DC.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Cell Balance
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: (c) 2004 by Victor Olaya. Cell Balance Calculation<br/><br/>References:<br/><br/> 1. Olaya, V. Hidrologia computacional y modelos digitales del terreno. Alqua. 536 pp. 2004

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Melton Ruggedness Number
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Melton ruggedness number (MNR) is a simple flow accumulation related index, calculated as difference between maximum and minimum elevation in catchment area divided by square root of catchment area size. The calculation is performed for each grid cell, therefore minimum elevation is same as elevation at cell's position. Due to the discrete character of a single maximum elevation, flow calculation is simply done with Deterministic 8. <br/><br/>References:<br/>Marchi, L. & Fontana, G.D. (2005): GIS morphometric indicators for the analysis of sediment dynamics in mountain basins. Environ. Geol. 48:218-228, DOI 10.1007/s00254-005-1292-4.<br/><br/>Melton M.A. (1965): The geomorphic and paleoclimatic significance of alluvial deposits in Southern Arizona. J. Geol. 73:1-38.<br/><br/>O'Callaghan, J.F. / Mark, D.M. (1984): The extraction of drainage networks from digital elevation data. Computer Vision, Graphics and Image Processing 28:323-344.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Slope Limited Flow Accumulation
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Flow accumulation is calculated as upslope contributing (catchment) area using the multiple flow direction approach of Freeman (1991). For this tool the approach has been modified to limit the flow portion routed through a cell depending on the local slope. If a cell is not inclined, no flow is routed through it at all. With increasing slopes the portion of flow routed through a cell becomes higher. Cells with slopes greater than a specified slope threshold route their entire accumulated flow downhill. <br/>References:<br/>- Freeman, G.T. (1991): Calculating catchment area with divergent flow based on a regular grid. Computers and Geosciences, 17:413-22<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Edge Contamination
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This tool uses flow directions to estimate possible contamination effects moving from outside of the grid passing the edge into its interior. This means that derived contributing area values might be underestimated for the marked cells. Cells not contamined will be marked as no data.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Catchment Area (Recursive)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Recursive upward processing of cells for calculation of flow accumulation and related parameters. This set of algorithms processes recursively all upwards connected cells until each cell of the DEM has been processed.<br/><br/>References:<br/><br/>Deterministic 8<br/>- O'Callaghan, J.F. / Mark, D.M. (1984):<br/> 'The extraction of drainage networks from digital elevation data',<br/> Computer Vision, Graphics and Image Processing, 28:323-344<br/><br/>Rho 8:<br/>- Fairfield, J. / Leymarie, P. (1991):<br/> 'Drainage networks from grid digital elevation models',<br/> Water Resources Research, 27:709-717<br/><br/>Deterministic Infinity:<br/>- Tarboton, D.G. (1997):<br/> 'A new method for the determination of flow directions and upslope areas in grid digital elevation models',<br/> Water Resources Research, Vol.33, No.2, p.309-319<br/><br/>Multiple m_Flow Direction:<br/>- Freeman, G.T. (1991):<br/> 'Calculating catchment area with divergent flow based on a regular grid',<br/> Computers and Geosciences, 17:413-22<br/><br/>- Quinn, P.F. / Beven, K.J. / Chevallier, P. / Planchon, O. (1991):<br/> 'The prediction of hillslope flow paths for distributed hydrological modelling using digital terrain models',<br/> Hydrological Processes, 5:59-79<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Slope Length
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Slope Length

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Topographic Wetness Index (TWI)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculation of the slope and specific catchment area (SCA) based Topographic Wetness Index (TWI)<br/><br/>References:<br/><br/>Beven, K.J., Kirkby, M.J. (1979):<br/>A physically-based variable contributing area model of basin hydrology'<br/>Hydrology Science Bulletin 24(1), p.43-69<br/><br/>Boehner, J., Selige, T. (2006):<br/>Spatial Prediction of Soil Attributes Using Terrain Analysis and Climate Regionalisation'<br/>In: Boehner, J., McCloy, K.R., Strobl, J.: 'SAGA - Analysis and Modelling Applications', Goettinger Geographische Abhandlungen, Vol.115, p.13-27<br/><br/>Moore, I.D., Grayson, R.B., Ladson, A.R. (1991):<br/>'Digital terrain modelling: a review of hydrogical, geomorphological, and biological applications'<br/>Hydrological Processes, Vol.5, No.1<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Catchment Area (Top-Down)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Top-down processing of cells for calculation of flow accumulation and related parameters. This set of algorithms processes a DEM downwards from the highest to the lowest cell.<br/><br/>References:<br/><br/>Deterministic 8<br/>- O'Callaghan, J.F. / Mark, D.M. (1984):<br/> 'The extraction of drainage networks from digital elevation data',<br/> Computer Vision, Graphics and Image Processing, 28:323-344<br/><br/>Rho 8:<br/>- Fairfield, J. / Leymarie, P. (1991):<br/> 'Drainage networks from grid digital elevation models',<br/> Water Resources Research, 27:709-717<br/><br/>Braunschweiger Reliefmodell:<br/>- Bauer, J. / Rohdenburg, H. / Bork, H.-R. (1985):<br/> 'Ein Digitales Reliefmodell als Vorraussetzung fuer ein deterministisches Modell der Wasser- und Stoff-Fluesse',<br/> Landschaftsgenese und Landschaftsoekologie, H.10, Parameteraufbereitung fuer deterministische Gebiets-Wassermodelle,<br/> Grundlagenarbeiten zu Analyse von Agrar-Oekosystemen, (Eds.: Bork, H.-R. / Rohdenburg, H.), p.1-15<br/><br/>Deterministic Infinity:<br/>- Tarboton, D.G. (1997):<br/> 'A new method for the determination of flow directions and upslope areas in grid digital elevation models',<br/> Water Resources Research, Vol.33, No.2, p.309-319<br/><br/>Multiple Flow Direction:<br/>- Freeman, G.T. (1991):<br/> 'Calculating catchment area with divergent flow based on a regular grid',<br/> Computers and Geosciences, 17:413-22<br/><br/>- Quinn, P.F. / Beven, K.J. / Chevallier, P. / Planchon, O. (1991):<br/> 'The prediction of hillslope flow paths for distributed hydrological modelling using digital terrain models',<br/> Hydrological Processes, 5:59-79<br/><br/>Triangular Multiple Flow Direction<br/>- Seibert, J. / McGlynn, B. (2007):<br/> 'A new triangular multiple flow direction algorithm for computing upslope areas from gridded digital elevation models',<br/> Water Resources Research, Vol. 43, W04501<br/> C++ Implementation into SAGA by Thomas Grabs, Copyrights (c) 2007<br/> Contact: thomas.grabs@natgeo.su.se, jan.seibert@natgeo.su.se <br/><br/>Multiple Flow Direction based on Maximum Downslope Gradient:<br/>- Qin, C. Z. / Zhu, A. X. / Pei, T. / Li, B. L. / Scholten, T. / Behrens, T. / & Zhou, C. H. (2011):<br/> 'An approach to computing topographic wetness index based on maximum downslope gradient',<br/> Precision Agriculture, 12(1), 32-43.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: LS Factor
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculation of slope length (LS) factor as used by the Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE), based on slope and specific catchment area (SCA, as substitute for slope length). <br/>References:<br/><br/>Boehner, J., Selige, T. (2006):<br/>Spatial Prediction of Soil Attributes Using Terrain Analysis and Climate Regionalisation'<br/>In: Boehner, J., McCloy, K.R., Strobl, J.: 'SAGA - Analysis and Modelling Applications', Goettinger Geographische Abhandlungen, Vol.115, p.13-27<br/><br/>Desmet & Govers (1996):<br/>'A GIS Procedure for Automatically Calculating the USLE LS Factor on Topographically Complex Landscape Units'<br/>Journal of Soil and Water Conservation, 51(5):427.433<br/><br/>Kinnell, P.I.A. (2005):<br/>'Alternative Approaches for Determining the USLE-M Slope Length Factor for Grid Cells.'<br/><a href="http://soil.scijournals.org/cgi/content/full/69/3/674">http://soil.scijournals.org/cgi/content/full/69/3/674</a><br/><br/>Moore, I.D., Grayson, R.B., Ladson, A.R. (1991):<br/>'Digital terrain modelling: a review of hydrogical, geomorphological, and biological applications'<br/>Hydrological Processes, Vol.5, No.1<br/><br/>Wischmeier, W.H., Smith, D.D. (1978):<br/>'Predicting rainfall erosion losses - A guide to conservation planning'<br/>Agriculture Handbook No. 537: US Department of Agriculture, Washington DC.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Flow Path Length
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module calculates the average flow path length starting from the seeds, that are given by the optional 'Seeds' grid and optionally from cells without upslope contributing areas (i.e. summits, ridges). Seeds will be all grid cells, that are not 'no data' values. If seeds are not given, only summits and ridges as given by the flow routing will be taken into account. Available flow routing methods are based on the 'Deterministic 8 (D8)' (Callaghan and Mark 1984) and the 'Multiple Flow Direction (FD8)' (Freeman 1991, Quinn et al. 1991) algorithms.<br/><br/>References:<br/><br/>Deterministic 8<br/>- O'Callaghan, J.F. / Mark, D.M. (1984):<br/> 'The extraction of drainage networks from digital elevation data',<br/> Computer Vision, Graphics and Image Processing, 28:323-344<br/><br/>- Freeman, G.T. (1991):<br/> 'Calculating catchment area with divergent flow based on a regular grid',<br/> Computers and Geosciences, 17:413-22<br/><br/>- Quinn, P.F. / Beven, K.J. / Chevallier, P. / Planchon, O. (1991):<br/> 'The prediction of hillslope flow paths for distributed hydrological modelling using digital terrain models',<br/> Hydrological Processes, 5:59-79<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Upslope Area
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module allows you to specify target cells, for which the upslope contributing area shall be identified. The result will give for each cell the percentage of its flow that reaches the target cell(s).<br/><br/>References:<br/><br/>Deterministic 8<br/>- O'Callaghan, J.F. / Mark, D.M. (1984):<br/> 'The extraction of drainage networks from digital elevation data',<br/> Computer Vision, Graphics and Image Processing, 28:323-344<br/><br/>Deterministic Infinity:<br/>- Tarboton, D.G. (1997):<br/> 'A new method for the determination of flow directions and upslope areas in grid digital elevation models',<br/> Water Resources Research, Vol.33, No.2, p.309-319<br/><br/>Multiple Flow Direction:<br/>- Freeman, G.T. (1991):<br/> 'Calculating catchment area with divergent flow based on a regular grid',<br/> Computers and Geosciences, 17:413-22<br/><br/>- Quinn, P.F. / Beven, K.J. / Chevallier, P. / Planchon, O. (1991):<br/> 'The prediction of hillslope flow paths for distributed hydrological modelling using digital terrain models',<br/> Hydrological Processes, 5:59-79<br/><br/>_______<br/><br/>This version uses all valid cells (not 'no data' values) of a given target grid to determine the contributing area. In case no target grid is provided as input, the specified x/y coordinates are used as target point.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Lake Flood
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module can be used to flood a digital elevation model from seed points. Seed points have to be coded either with local water depth or absolute water level.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Flow Width and Specific Catchment Area
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Flow width and specific catchment area (SCA) calculation.<br/><br/>References:<br/>Gruber, S., Peckham, S. (2008): Land-Surface Parameters and Objects in Hydrology. In: Hengl, T. and Reuter, H.I. [Eds.]: Geomorphometry: Concepts, Software, Applications. Developments in Soil Science, Elsevier, 33:293-308.<br/><br/>Quinn, P.F., Beven, K.J., Chevallier, P., Planchon, O. (1991): The prediction of hillslope flow paths for distributed hydrological modelling using digital terrain models. Hydrological Processes, 5:59-79<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Catchment Area (Flow Tracing)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Flow tracing algorithms for calculations of flow accumulation and related parameters. These algorithms trace the flow of each cell in a DEM separately until it finally leaves the DEM or ends in a sink.<br/><br/>References:<br/><br/>Rho 8 (this implementation adopted the original algorithm only for the flow routing and will give quite different results):<br/>- Fairfield, J. / Leymarie, P. (1991):<br/> 'Drainage networks from grid digital elevation models',<br/> Water Resources Research, 27:709-717<br/><br/>Kinematic Routing Algorithm:<br/>- Lea, N.L. (1992):<br/> 'An aspect driven kinematic routing algorithm',<br/> in: Parsons, A.J., Abrahams, A.D. (Eds.), 'Overland Flow: hydraulics and erosion mechanics', London, 147-175<br/><br/>DEMON:<br/>- Costa-Cabral, M. / Burges, S.J. (1994):<br/> 'Digital Elevation Model Networks (DEMON): a model of flow over hillslopes for computation of contributing and dispersal areas',<br/> Water Resources Research, 30:1681-1692<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Stream Power Index
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculation of stream power index based on slope and specific catchment area (SCA).<br/>SPI = SCA * tan(Slope)<br/><br/>References:<br/><br/>Moore, I.D., Grayson, R.B., Ladson, A.R. (1991):<br/>'Digital terrain modelling: a review of hydrogical, geomorphological, and biological applications'<br/>Hydrological Processes, Vol.5, No.1<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: TCI Low
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Terrain Classification Index for Lowlands (TCI Low).<br/><br/>Reference:<br/>Bock, M., Boehner, J., Conrad, O., Koethe, R., Ringeler, A. (2007): Methods for creating Functional Soil Databases and applying Digital Soil Mapping with SAGA GIS. In: Hengl, T., Panagos, P., Jones, A., Toth, G. [Eds.]: Status and prospect of soil information in south-eastern Europe: soil databases, projects and applications. EUR 22646 EN Scientific and Technical Research series, Office for Official Publications of the European Communities, Luxemburg, p.149-162. <a target="_blank" href="http://eusoils.jrc.ec.europa.eu/ESDB_Archive/eusoils_docs/esb_rr/EUR22646EN.pdf">online</a>.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Catchment Area (Mass-Flux Method)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The Mass-Flux Method (MFM) for the DEM based calculation of flow accumulation as proposed by Gruber and Peckham (2008).<br/><br/>!!!UNDER DEVELOPMENT!!! To be done: solving the streamline resolution problem<br/><br/>References:<br/>Gruber, S., Peckham, S. (2008): Land-Surface Parameters and Objects in Hydrology. In: Hengl, T. and Reuter, H.I. [Eds.]: Geomorphometry: Concepts, Software, Applications. Developments in Soil Science, Elsevier, Bd.33, S.293-308.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Wind Effect (Windward / Leeward Index)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The 'Wind Effect' is a dimensionless index. Values below 1 indicate wind shadowed areas whereas values above 1 indicate areas exposed to wind, all with regard to the specified wind direction. Wind direction, i.e. the direction into which the wind blows, might be either constant or variying in space, if a wind direction grid is supplied.<br/><br/>References:<br/>- Boehner, J., Antonic, O. (2009): 'Land-surface parameters specific to topo-climatology'. in: Hengl, T., Reuter, H. (Eds.): 'Geomorphometry - Concepts, Software, Applications'. Developments in Soil Science, Volume 33, p.195-226, Elsevier.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Hypsometry
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Calculates the hypsometric curve for a given DEM.<br/><br/>The hypsometric curve is an empirical cumulative distribution function of elevations in a catchment or of a whole planet. The module calculates both the relative (scaled from 0 to 100 percent) and absolute (minimum to maximum values) distributions. The former scales elevation and area by the maximum values. Such a non-dimensional curve allows one to asses the similarity of watersheds as differences in hypsometric curves arise from different geomorphic processes shaping a landscape.<br/><br/>In case the hypsometric curve should not be calculated for the whole elevation range of the input dataset, a user-specified elevation range can be specified with the classification constant area.<br/><br/>The output table has two attribute columns with relative height and area values, and two columns with absolute height and area values. In order to plot the non-dimensional hypsometric curve as diagram, use the relative area as x-axis values and the relative height for the y-axis. For a diagram with absolute values, use the absolute area as x-axis values and the absolute height for the y-axis.<br/><br/>References:<br/>- Harlin, J.M (1978):<br/> 'Statistical moments of the hypsometric curve and its density function',<br/> J. Int. Assoc. Math. Geol., Vol.10, p.59-72<br/><br/>- Luo, W. (2000):<br/> 'Quantifying groundwater-sapping landforms with a hypsometric technique',<br/> J. of Geophysical Research, Vol.105, No.E1, p.1685-1694<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Fuzzy Landform Element Classification
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Algorithm for derivation of form elements according to slope, maximum curvature, minimum curvature, profile curvature, tangential curvature, based on a linear semantic import model for slope and curvature and a fuzzy classification Based on the AML script 'felementf' by Jochen Schmidt, Landcare Research. <br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Downslope Distance Gradient

Rodhe, A. (2004): 'A new topographic index to quantify downslope controls on local drainage', Water Resources Research, 40<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Morphometric Features
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Uses a multi-scale approach by fitting quadratic parameters to any size window (via least squares) to derive slope, aspect and curvatures (optional output) for subsequent classification of morphometric features (peaks, ridges, passes, channels, pits and planes). This is the method as proposed and implemented by Jo Wood (1996) in LandSerf and GRASS GIS (r.param.scale). <br/><br/>Optional output is described in the following. Generalised elevation is the smoothed input DEM. Slope is the magnitude of maximum gradient. It is given for steepest slope angle and measured in degrees. Aspect is the direction of maximum gradient. Profile curvature is the curvature intersecting with the plane defined by the Z axis and maximum gradient direction. Positive values describe convex profile curvature, negative values concave profile. Plan curvature is the horizontal curvature, intersecting with the XY plane. Longitudinal curvature is the profile curvature intersecting with the plane defined by the surface normal and maximum gradient direction. Cross-sectional curvature is the tangential curvature intersecting with the plane defined by the surface normal and a tangent to the contour - perpendicular to maximum gradient direction. Minimum curvature is measured in direction perpendicular to the direction of of maximum curvature. The maximum curvature is measured in any direction. <br/><br/>References:<br/><br/>Wood, J. (1996): The Geomorphological characterisation of Digital Elevation Models. Diss., Department of Geography, University of Leicester, U.K. <a target="_blank" href="http://www.soi.city.ac.uk/~jwo/phd/">online</a>.<br/><br/>Wood, J. (2009): Geomorphometry in LandSerf. In: Hengl, T. and Reuter, H.I. [Eds.]: Geomorphometry: Concepts, Software, Applications. Developments in Soil Science, Elsevier, Vol.33, 333-349.<br/><br/><a target="_blank" href="http://www.landserf.org/">LandSerf Homepage</a>.

K. (1981):<br/> 'Hill shading and the relectance map',<br/> Proceedings of the IEEE, v. 69, no. 1, p. 14-47.<br/><br/>- Beasley, D.B., Huggins, L.F. wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Fill Sinks XXL (Wang & Liu)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module uses an algorithm proposed by Wang & Liu to identify and fill surface depressions in digital elevation models.<br/>The method was enhanced to allow the creation of hydrologic sound elevation models, i.e. not only to fill the depression(s) but also to preserve a downward slope along the flow path. If desired, this is accomplished by preserving a minimum slope gradient (and thus elevation difference) between cells.<br/>This version of the module is designed to work on large data sets (e.g. LIDAR data), with smaller datasets you might like to check out the fully featured standard version of the module.<br/><br/><br/>References:<br/>Wang, L. & H. Liu (2006): An efficient method for identifying and filling surface depressions in digital elevation models for hydrologic analysis and modelling. International Journal of Geographical Information Science, Vol. 20, No. 2: 193-213.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Burn Stream Network into DEM
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Burns a stream network into a Digital Elevation Model (DEM). Stream cells have to be coded with valid data values, all other cells should be set to no data value. First two methods decrease . The third method ensures a steady downstream gradient. An elevation decrease is only applied, if a downstream cell is equally high or higher. You should provide a grid with flow directions for determination of downstream cells. The 'Sink Drainage Route Detection' module offers such flow directions.

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Fill Sinks (Wang & Liu)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: This module uses an algorithm proposed by Wang & Liu to identify and fill surface depressions in digital elevation models.<br/>The method was enhanced to allow the creation of hydrologic sound elevation models, i.e. not only to fill the depression(s) but also to preserve a downward slope along the flow path. If desired, this is accomplished by preserving a minimum slope gradient (and thus elevation difference) between cells.<br/>This is the fully featured version of the module creating a depression less DEM, a flow path grid and a grid with watershed basins. If you encounter problems processing large data sets (e.g. LIDAR data) with this module try the basic version (Fill Sinks XXL).<br/><br/><br/>References:<br/>Wang, L. & H. Liu (2006): An efficient method for identifying and filling surface depressions in digital elevation models for hydrologic analysis and modelling. International Journal of Geographical Information Science, Vol. 20, No. 2: 193-213.<br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Fill Sinks (Planchon/Darboux, 2001)
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Depression filling algorithm after Olivier Planchon & Frederic Darboux (2001)<br/><br/><br/>References:<br/>Planchon, O. & F. Darboux (2001): A fast, simple and versatile algorithm to fill the depressions of digital elevation models. Catena 46: 159-176<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Sink Removal
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Sink Removal

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Reclassify Grid Values
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: The module can be used to reclassify the values of a grid. It provides three different options:<br/>(a) reclassification of single values<br/>(b) reclassification of a range of values<br/>(c) reclassification of value ranges specified in a lookup table<br/><br/>In addition to these methods, two special cases (NoData values and values not included in the reclassification setup) are supported.<br/>With reclassification mode (a) and (b), the 'NoData option' is evaluated before the 'Method' settings. In reclassification mode (c) the option is evaluated only if the NoData value is not included in the lookup table.<br/>The 'other values' option is always evaluated after checking the 'Method' settings.<br/><br/>The module allows one to define the NoData value of the output grid (header): by default, the output grid gets assigned the NoData value of the input grid. But it is also possible to assign a user defined NoData value.<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Close Gaps with Spline

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Title: Shrink and Expand
wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Regions with valid data in the input grid can be shrinked or expanded by a certain amount (radius). Shrinking just sets the border of regions with valid data to NoData, expanding sets NoData cells along the border of regions with valid data to a new valid value, computed by the method selected (min, max, mean, majority).<br/><br/>

wps:ProcessSummary.ows:Abstract: Tiling
